summary: Imagine thinking Daenerys only cares for the throne after she literally risked the life of her greatest weapons and herself to...
body:
Imagine thinking Daenerys only cares for the throne after she literally risked the life of her greatest weapons and herself to save Jon Snow and his crew beyond the wall where millions of ice zombies live because she obviously loves herself more than anything and is super power hungry.

Ugh, can’t relate.

reblog.comment:

blog.description:
| Angie | Argentina | 24 | She/Her | Literature student |
House Stark. Rebel scum. Hufflepuff. Greek mythology lover. Sansa Stark defense squad. Salty winter adult. Fangirl with a lot of feelings. Icon by treasonforlove. Mobile header by ohbellamy. Sidebar gif by iheartgot.

tags: i know not everyone knows about tropes
but to call people the shit of the fandom because they correctly observed a pattern and identified a trope
especially when it's a well-known and extremely used trope
i'm gonna call bullshit on that
tptb gave us these pics so...
title: The Kubrick Stare
body:
(Inspired by @thegratefulned’s (x) and @oursistheendgame’s (x) posts and also because some people don’t know their tropes, so here it goes)

The Kubrick Stare is used mostly by villains, and is a way to let the audience know about what’s coming next in the story. It can also serve as a way to show the audience a dark turn in a character’s mind, the externalisation of their dark thoughts. The look works as a warning: it’s ominous and intimidating; it’s as though the character is looking into our own eyes.

There are many examples in cinema and television. The most famous one is probably the one showed by Malcom McDowell’s Alex DeLarge in A Clockwork Orange. (You can use any film by Kubrick, tbh. The trope is named after him,a fter all)

This look comes before Alex and his group of friends beat up people on the street and before he rapes and ultimately kills a woman. This look works as a red flag. We know Alex is dangerous before he commits any crime.


Another well-know Kubrick Stare is the one given by Anthony Perkin’s Norman Bates at the end of Psycho.

The look comes after the audience discovers Norman’s “Mother” personality. We know he killed his mother and her lover, two women (events that took place before the film), Marion and the detective. We also know that this personality has taken hold of him. So we watch Norman in an empty room, while hearing “Mother” in a voice-over stating that the person responsible for the murders was Norman all along. The voice-over ends with the Kubrick Stare. It’s there to put the audience at unease, to leave the audience wondering: “Could it be that it was Norman all along and that he managed to fool everyone?” 


The Kubrick Stare is a trope, and an old one at that. So when people point out this

it’s not because they are desperate, it’s because they recognize a trope that has been heavily featured in media since silent film era

Rudolf Klein-Rogge in The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari (1920)


Rudolf Klein-Rogge in The Testament of Dr. Mabuse (1933)


Like I said at the beggining of this post, the Kubrick Stare is ominous and unsettling. It’s not only a visual tool (to show the audience the dark nature of a character), but it’s also there to stir emotion and reaction from the audience. A character gives someone this look and we just know what follows will not be good or nice.

So why these three characters? Well, that is because of these three characters’ capacity of destruction. All three are connected to storms:

Jon Snow (talking about the Night King): […] The true enemy won’t wait out the storm. He brings the storm.

Euron Greyjoy (talking to his brother Balon, before killing him): I am the storm, brother. The first storm and the last.

Daenerys (to the Spice King in Qarth): I am not your little princess. I am Daenerys Stormborn of the blood of old Valyria and I will take what is mine, with fire and blood I will take it.

Thus far, these are the only characters that are associated to storms, either by themselves or their enemies. The Night King is the stormbringer, Euron is the storm and Daenerys is the stormborn.

In literature, a storm is associated with destruction, violence and death. It can also be used as foreshadowing. It sets the mood. It’s been used as symbolism from the 8th century BC. From Homer, in which a storm is associated with turmoil and hardship, to William Shakespeare, in which a storm is associated with madness, storm symbolism is hardly new. 

So it’s not all that surprising that for the last promo for the series, the only three characters associated with storms (destruction, violence and death) are given the Kubrick Stare. It sets the mood for the last act of GOT: it’s there to stir emotion in us. We are meant to feel unsettled. It’s ominous; it’s there to remind us of the destructive force these three characters represent.

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary:
Disappointed but not surprised
I just knew there was gonna be that one that singled out Daenerys for looking 'antagonistic'....
body:
Disappointed but not surprised

I just knew there was gonna be that one that singled out Daenerys for looking ‘antagonistic’.

They’re all meant to look edgy and goth for the aesthetic you fool.
